January 1, 2012: Fiction
11/22/63, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $35.) An English teacher travels back to
1958 by way of a time portal in a Maine diner. His assignment is to stop Lee
Harvey Oswald.
LOCKED ON, by Tom Clancy with Mark Greaney. (Putnam, $28.95.) Jack Ryan
Jr. must stop an emerging threat from a Pakistani general.
THE LITIGATORS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) Partners in a small
law firm take on a big case after a fast-track burnout joins them.
KILL ALEX CROSS, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $28.99.) Alex Cross
investigates when the president’s children are kidnapped, but the F.BI. and C.I.A.
stand in his way.
DEATH COMES TO PEMBERLEY, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $25.95.) Six years
after Elizabeth Bennet and Darcy marry, their comfortable life is shaken by a
murder, as James recreates the world of “Pride and Prejudice” with a mysterious
twist.
THE BEST OF ME, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central, $25.99.) Twenty-five
years after their high school romance ended, a man and woman who have gone
their separate ways return to their North Carolina town for the funeral of a friend.
RED MIST, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $27.95.) The chief medical examiner
Kay Scarpetta investigates a string of killings she believes are linked to the murder
of her former deputy; the 19th Scarpetta book.
EXPLOSIVE EIGHTEEN, by Janet Evanovich. (Bantam, $28.) After a disastrous
vacation in Hawaii, Stephanie Plum becomes the target of an international killer.
THE DROP, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Harry Bosch of the
L.A.P.D. uncovers both the operations of a sadistic killer and a political conspiracy.
V IS FOR VENGEANCE, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27.95.)
Pursuing a shoplifter, Kinsey Millhone discovers that retail crime is run by
organized gangs.
THE ART OF FIELDING, by Chad Harbach. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) A gifted but
vulnerable ballplayer faces a crisis.
1Q84, by Haruki Murakami. (Knopf, $30.5.) In 1980s Tokyo, a woman who
punishes perpetrators of domestic violence has ties to an aspiring novelist with an
unusual project.
MICRO, by Michael Crichton and Richard Preston. (Harper/HarperCollins,
$28.99.) Seven graduate students, miniaturized by an evil entrepreneur, do battle
with insects in the Hawaiian rain forest.
January 1, 2012
Non-Fiction
STEVE JOBS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the
recently deceased entrepreneur.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The heart-
stopping events surrounding the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
JACK KENNEDY, by Chris Matthews. (Simon & Schuster, $27.5.) An admiring
portrait.
BEING GEORGE WASHINGTON, by Glenn Beck and Kevin Balfe. (Threshold
Editions/Mercury Radio Arts, $26.) How Washington turned himself into the
indispensable man.
THROUGH MY EYES, by Tim Tebow with Nathan Whitaker. (HarperCollins,
$26.99.) The Broncos quarterback chronicles his personal and professional course.
THINKING, FAST AND SLOW, by Daniel Kahneman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.)
The winner of the Nobel in economic science discusses how we make choices in
business and personal life and when we can and cannot trust our intuitions.
CATHERINE THE GREAT, by Robert K. Massie. (Random House, $35.) The life of
the minor 18th-century German princess who became Empress of All the Russias.
THEN AGAIN, by Diane Keaton. (Random House, $26.) The actress uses her
mother’s diaries as a springboard for the examination of her own life.
HEAVEN IS FOR REAL, by Todd Burpo with Lynn Vincent. (Thomas Nelson,
$21.99.) A boy’s encounter with Jesus and the angels during an emergency
appendectomy.
IN THE GARDEN OF BEASTS, by Erik Larson. (Crown, $26.) William E. Dodd, the
U.S. ambassador to Germany, and his daughter, Martha, in 1930s Berlin.
BOOMERANG, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $25.95.) A look at some of the places
hardest hit by the recent financial collapse.
A HISTORY OF THE WORLD IN 100 OBJECTS, by Neil MacGregor. (Viking, $45.)
British Museum curators attempt to tell the story of mankind through objects in the
museum’s collections.
BOSSYPANTS, by Tina Fey. (Reagan Arthur/Little, Brown, $26.99.) A memoir from
the creator of "30 Rock."
DESTINY OF THE REPUBLIC, by Candice Millard. (Doubleday, $28.95.) The life
